title: "Proof-of-Age (PoA): A Consensus Algorithm Encouraging Solo Mining"
description: >-
  Introducing a consensus algorithm that undermines the performance of mining pools, which threatens the decentralization of Bitcoin, in order to promote solo mining.

### How Bitcoin Stays Decentralized: Proof-of-Work (PoW)
In blockchain, mining refers to establishing a block's ownership by a consensus algorithm. There are several consensus algorithms, but Bitcoin uses Proof-of-Work (PoW). PoW is an algorithm that rewards ownership of a block by showing that you’ve put in the “computational effort” to find a particular result. At this time, anyone can receive a reward as long as they make a “computational effort” and find the answer first, and since all participants in the network verify the validity of the solution together, the blockchain can maintain decentralization.

Bitcoin’s PoW allows mining to occur approximately every 10 minutes by adjusting the difficulty of mining accordingly. The difficulty is adjusted by checking the average mining time interval between blocks every 2016 blocks and increasing the difficulty if the interval is narrower than 10 minutes and decreasing the difficulty if it is wider.

Mining difficulty is related to “hashrate”. Hashrate is a measure of a miner’s computational power required for mining. In general, as the computational power of a miner increases, the time it takes to mine decreases and the difficulty increases, which can be understood as “increased hashrate≈ increased mining difficulty”.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa2.jpg){: width="600" height="589" }
_Bitcoin’s hashrate from 2016 until now. (Source: Coin Metrics, 2021)_

The graph above shows the hashrate of Bitcoin. Bitcoin’s Hashrate has been steadily moving upwards in the past. This means that the computer power required to successfully mine is getting higher and higher, making it harder and harder for individuals to mine.

### The Rise of Mining Pools and How They Undermine Decentralization
The reason why mining becomes difficult for individuals is due to computational processing power limitations, so groups of people have emerged to compute together. These are called mining pools. A mining pool connects multiple miners to perform computations like a supercomputer and distributes mining rewards based on the ratio of each miner’s hash power. In this case, hash power refers to the computational processing power of each miner.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa3.jpg){: width="900" height="589" }
_Distribution of the Bitcoin network’s hashrate (Source: Blockchain.com, 2019)_

However, mining pools have recently grown in size, threatening the decentralization of Bitcoin. The chart above shows the hashrate share of mining pools on the Bitcoin network. Bitcoin is able to keep malicious participants in check during the consensus process as long as they do not exceed 51% of the total. However, the combined hashpower of two or three current mining pools is close to 51%, making it possible for transactions to be manipulated. This expansion of mining pools undermines the decentralization of Bitcoin’s underlying philosophy and needs to be addressed.

### PoA (Proof-of-Age): A Consensus Algorithm that Leads to Solo Mining

Mining pools are not good for Bitcoin’s decentralization, so we need to encourage solo mining.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa4.jpg){: width="600" height="589" }
_Pooling is not Favorable: Decentralize Mining Power of PoW Blockchain Using Age-of-Work_

The paper *“Pooling is not Favorable: Decentralize Mining Power of PoW Blockchain Using Age-of-Work (by Long Shi, Taotao Wang, Jun Li, and Shengli Zhang)”*, pictured above, proposes a Proof-of-Age (PoA) consensus algorithm that induces solo mining.

PoA is built on the framework of PoW (Proof-of-Work) and inherits the basic properties of PoW. However, unlike PoW, which rewards only the first-place winner, PoA rewards according to the “Effective Mining Period,” which is the period during which the participant actively attempts to mine, even if the mining is not successful. (The exact meaning of “actively trying to mine” will be explained later (in “D. Mining Results.”)) Since mining competition is necessary to maintain the Bitcoin network, PoA rewards not only first place, but also competitors who contribute to the maintenance of the blockchain, and adjusts the degree of reward for each miner, creating an incentive for independent mining.

We’ll explain the design of PoA in five parts. This section assumes a basic understanding of the Bitcoin block structure and block generation process.

- Hash Puzzle
- Age Ring
- Age-of-Work (AoW)
- Mining Outcomes
- Difficulty Adjustment

#### A. Hash Puzzle
A hash puzzle is a problem that needs to be solved using computational power in PoW. First, let’s look at a hash puzzle in PoW.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa5.jpg){: width="500" height="589" }
_Hash Puzzle of PoW_

k is the height of the candidate block (how many blocks up the chain it is). H() is a cryptographic hash function. Let h_{k} be a sequence of bits resulting from H(), of length L. As input to H(), b_{k-1} is the hash of the previous block header, x_{k} is the nonce (answer value), and y_{k} is the hash of other data in the candidate block (such as the Merkle root of a transaction). D is the difficulty of the hash puzzle and T(D) is the target value. Since difficulty means that the D most significant bits of the hash value must be zero as a condition for a correct answer, T(D) is expressed as 2^{L-D}.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa6.jpg){: width="700" height="589" }

Therefore, as shown in the equation above, the probability of finding a block hash less than or equal to T(D) decreases as the difficulty D increases. Conversely, as D decreases, the probability increases.

If we extend this hash puzzle to PoA, it looks like this

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa7.jpg){: width="400" height="589" }
_Hash Puzzle of PoA_

Unlike PoW, r_{k} and PK_{i} are added. r_{k} is the “age ring” of a miner in a block of height k, and PK_{i} is the public key of miner i.

#### B. Age Ring
So what is an age ring?

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa8.jpg){: width="700" height="589" }

Miner i wants to mine a block of height k. At this point, miner i has a history of successfully mining a block at k-n. In this case, miner i’s age ring in block l is equal to the above expression. w_{l} is the argument that proves the validity of r_{l}, and the method of generating w_{l} will be explained in “D. Mining output”. First, note that w_{l} in a block is initialized to NULL (nonzero since it’s a bitstream operation) immediately after successful mining. b_{l-1} is the hash of the l-1st block header. <.> is a concatenating operation that concatenates the arguments in order.

In simple terms, r_{l} is the value derived from the hash value of the previous block (b_{l-1}) and the age ring of the previous block (r_{l-1}). This means that there is another chain that is independent of the main blockchain, but related to it. As illustrated below:

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa9.jpg){: width="900" height="589" }

In the picture, the square chains represent blockchains and the circled chains represent age rings. I thought about what the original Ring could be a metaphor for and realized that it was meant to represent a key ring on a key. The age rings we’re going to talk about are like key chains attached to the main chain. Because age rings are present in every block and dependent on each other, they exist in the form of a chain, and “each miner” has one of those chains. (This is a completely different concept from sidechains).

#### C. Age-of-Work (AoW)
So, let’s use an “age chain” to represent how long a participant has been actively mining, or in other words, their “age”.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa10.jpg){: width="400" height="589" }
![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa11.jpg){: width="500" height="589" }

Δ_{i}(l) is the Age-of-Work (AoW) that miner i has on a block of height l. We can interpret AoW as “age”. As shown in the expression above, miner i ages one year every time they “actively” participate in mining. And when they successfully mine, their age is reset to 0.

#### D. Mining Outcomes
So how do we know that someone has actively attempted to mine, and how do we validate the age rings? This paper addresses both of these needs in a very innovative way.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa12.jpg){: width="900" height="589" }
_An illustration of three different mining outcomes._

First of all, to judge the user’s activeness, we use the region of the result of the Hash Puzzle of PoA expression in “A. Hash Puzzle” as a reference. T_{M} is the target value of block mining, T_{A} is the target value of the age ring, and 2^L is the region of all possible results. Then T_{M} < T_{A} ≤ 2^L. Here, T_{A} is a fixed value and can be reached with little computational effort. Unlike T_{A, the difficulty of T_{M} is scaled by the AoW. (Recall the hash puzzle expression where T_{M} has a difficulty D as an argument).

##### [ Result I ]
If the result is in the range 0 to T_{M}, you have found the correct answer for block mining.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa13.jpg){: width="500" height="589" }

In this case, the age ring’s w_{k} is reset to NULL, the AoW is initialized to 0, and the miner gets the main chain’s mining reward.

##### [ Result II ]
If the result falls between T_{M} and T_{A}, it means that you haven’t found the correct answer to mining the block, but you have tried to mine aggressively enough.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa14.jpg){: width="500" height="589" }

The value of x_{k} at this time becomes the value of w_{k} in the age chain, which is not the actual blockchain nonce value, but the value of x_{k} that shows activeness becomes w_{k}. This is how the correct answer to the age ring chain is found and the age ring is validated.

##### [ Result III ]
If the result is greater than T_{A}, then we have found neither the correct answer for block mining nor the correct answer for age ring mining.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa15.jpg){: width="500" height="589" }

So no change in value occurs.

#### E. Difficulty Adjustment
The difficulty is provided as a factor in T_{M} in “D. Mining output”. And this difficulty D is determined by the AoW. In this paper, we assign difficulty based on whether the AoW exceeds a threshold. For example, if the threshold is δ and we divide it into two regions, we have the following equation.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa16.jpg){: width="500" height="589" }

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa17.jpg){: width="150" height="589" }

If the AoW is less than or equal to δ, the difficulty is high; if it is greater than or equal to δ, the difficulty is low. In other words, miners who actively participate in mining but are not successful are rewarded with a lower difficulty.

#### Putting it all together. 
Let’s look again at the PoA hash puzzle expression we saw above.

![Desktop View](/assets/img/posts/proof-of-age/poa18.jpg){: width="400" height="589" }
_Hash Puzzle of PoA_

To mine the main blockchain, we need to know r_{k} in addition to x_{k}, which we had to find in the previous PoW. However, this r_{k} is the value generated by the w_{k} being mined. The AoW is then updated based on whether this r_{k} falls within T_{M}, T_{A}, or 2^L of the target value range. Finally, a miner who has been actively trying to mine, but has never succeeded, and has only been increasing the AoW value, will be rewarded with a lower difficulty (D2) when mining blocks, increasing the probability of successful mining.

The paper suggests the following five effects that can be derived from the proof-of-age we’ve seen so far. I suggest you extrapolate from the above.

> - Remark 1: Age-ring chains — Age-ring chains rely on the previous age-ring value and the hash value of the previous block. This has the advantage that it is pointless to precompute the age-ring chain separately, or to break up the chain to create confusion. 
- Remark 2: Negligible overhead of age ring — The age ring is included as one argument when generating the block hash value, so its overhead is negligible.
- Remark 3: Block verification — When a block is deployed, it includes a nonce value and an age ring, making it easy to verify that both values are appropriate.
- Remark 4: Sybil attack resistance — Miner i is identified by its public key PK_{i}. Even if we assume that a number of new participants come in for a Sybil attack, the AoW of all of them is initially set to 0, so they have to break through the high mining difficulty. Therefore, PoA can resist Sybil attacks.
- Remark 5: Memoryless mining — Memory is not used, so if you succeed in mining a valid age ring, you can put the age ring as an argument to the PoA hash puzzle and continue to mine blocks. This has the advantage of not using memory, so the probability of mining does not change.
